awd_abstract_narration:
The PI investigates manifestations of the classical/quantum (particle/wave) correspondence in mathematics. The quantum states or waves are described as solutions of partial differential equations and their properties are often determined by the properties of underlying classical (particle) systems. The subject has its origins in geometric optics (going back to the 17th century) and quantum mechanics (going back to the first half of the 20th century) but the numerical, experimental and mathematical advances provide a new range of challenges and research opportunities. For instance, quantum resonances, which in chemistry can describe transitional states in chemical reactions, are now more accessible experimentally, and mathematically, compared to the time when they were introduced. Quasinormal modes, which are an analogue of these resonances in general relativity now have a chance of being observed for the first time, thanks to the LIGO experiments. At the same time, the methods originally developed to study differential equations using insights from classical dynamics, are now successfully used to answer questions about chaotic systems or geometry of geodesics. The project provides research training opportunities for graduate students. 

Among the specific problems studied by the PI are: (1) distribution of scattering resonances for classically chaotic systems; (2) understand dynamical zeta function (generating function for periods of closed orbits in much the same way as the Riemann zeta function is a generating function of prime numbers); and (3) spectral problems arising in fluid mechanics, specifically in the formation of internal waves. The concrete problem about chaotic scattering concerns the existence of a spectral gap for any (hyperbolic) configuration of convex obstacles in the plane. Since the late 80s it was proposed in the mathematics and physics literature that the gap is determined by the "topological pressure" of the trapped reflected rays. Recent advances on the fractal uncertainty principle should imply that there always is a spectral gap. For dynamical zeta functions, one of the goals is to understand the Fried conjecture which proposes a relation between dynamical (value of the zeta function at 0), spectral and topological quantities (corresponding torsions) for general manifolds with chaotic flows. The microlocal tools developed, among others by the PI, are particularly promising here. Internal waves in fluids, theoretically described by spectral methods, have only been observed, in a controlled experiment, 25 years ago. The importance of viscosity and nonlinear effects (on both classical and wave level) is still to be fully understood. The PI and his collaborators made some advances here but many questions, such as the analysis of the physically relevant boundary value problems, remain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PI's work can be described as applied microlocal analysis. It is pure mathematics in the sense of (attempting/claiming) fully rigorous arguments but with motivation coming from problems arising in modern science. 

Microlocal analysis is, roughly, an investigation of classical/quantum (particle/wave) correspondence in the theory of partial differential equations (PDE) with manifestations in other fields of mathematics such as dynamical systems, representation theory or even algebraic geometry.  It relates objects from symplectic geometry (geometry describing and generalizing classical dynamics) to ``quantum" objects, such as solutions to PDE. The term microlocal was coined by Mikio Sato in 1973: one considers generalized functions not just locally in position but also,simultaneously, locally in frequency/momentum, hence microlocally. 

The research under this NSF grant concentrated on two topics: mathematics of condensed matter physics, more specifically, twisted two dimensional structures, and on dynamics of internal waves in stratified fluids. 

Twisted bilayer graphene (TBG) is obtained by twisting two sheets of graphene (a two dimensional crystalline realisation of carbon -- it is remarkably stable and was first obtained by peeling of sheets of carbon atoms from graphite -- as in pencil leads -- using scotch tape). At certain angles of twisting (named magic angles) TBG exhibits unusual properties such as superconductivity. The so-call chiral model of TBG has partiularly nice mathematical properties and was studied by the PI and his collaborators. We discovered a spectral characterization of magic angles, remarkable identities (such as that the sum of generalized magic angles to power 4 equals to 8 times pi divided by square root of three), exponential squeezing of bands and existence of classically forbidden regions based on properities of Poisson brackets. The beauty of the phenomema we encountered is exemplified by the enclosed image showing dynamics of Dirac points when TBG is put in a magnetic field in the direction of the 2D material.

A simple model for creation of internal waves in a “thin” aquarium is given by the Poincare equation (also relevant in the study of rotating fluids). Once physical constants are taken into account it provides a remarkably accurate model – see https://www. youtube.com/watch?v=6qgPdszHRzs – for the formation of internal waves. Their geometry was predicted by formal arguments by oceanographers and was experimentally observed in the late 1990’s. 

The PI participated in two major advances in this subject. Jeff Galkowski and the PI studied viscosity limits  and showed that as viscosity goes to 0, the eigenvalues of the corresponding operator converge (for frequencies at which natural dynamical conditions are satisfied) to complex ``resonances"; that required a build up of a machinery of complex microlocal deformations  which has had other applications. For instance,  we used that technology to prove an analytic hypoellipticity result motivated by the question of analyticity of quasinormal modes of black holes accross event horizons. Semyon Dyatlov, Jian Wang and the PI proved that under natural dynamical conditions (same as in the physics literature) and for domains with smooth boundaries, solutions to the Poincar ́e problem develop singularities with specific spatial and frequency localizations. This is illustrated in the enclosed figure showing a remarkable agreement of mathematical theory with experiments.
